channel.title: Leaving A Legacy (or at least ranting)
channel.description: Read about my adventures, relationships, and traumas. Continue on about my thoughts, thought processes, principles, and wrongdoings. Hear me judge but never judge me. Or I'll blacklist you from this blog.

item.title: Dear popo: leave Uber alone!
item.description:
"Our intention is to make Uber so efficient, cars so highly utilized that for most people it is cheaper than owning a car" - Travis Kalanick, CEO

We have an issue. The police have been trying to shut down Uber in Cape Town because Uber drivers have been taking away a massive amount of business from cab drivers while not paying taxes. Article link

The other day, my Uber driver asked me to move from the back seat to the front passenger seat so our ride would not appear to be a "business ride" to onlookers. I willingly did so, because I LOVE Uber here in Cape Town.

Why do I love Uber in CT?

1. Ubers are far safer than cabs in CT. My program director told me I am forbidden from riding in anything other than Uber on my own. Yes, cabs are unsafe. Article link

2. Ubers are incredibly cheap in CT. The minimum is R20, or $1.6. Compare that to the min in NYC of $8.

3. The drivers' names are hilarious.

So, please sign any petitions that arise in favor of keeping Uber out there to keep all of us Capetonians safe. Thank you!

item.title: Happy Birthday, Mommy!
item.description:
I think it is. 45 o cumplea√±os feliz a mi madre. You're still young enough to have a 9th baby!!!



You found this bru and made all of us.

You

+

=

Let's move on. I really don't want to get into those details.

I know I scream at you sometimes, but as I age I realize how stupid that is of me.

You almost always make the loveliest impressions on everyone (the only exception that comes to mind is your screaming at Acey- that little square face!- in front of Frank), including Gloria Hack, Marlee, Brooke, Judd/Denise (I said impression, not lasting impression), and everyone else who meets you.

A birthday greeting for you:

Dearest Mother,
I know I do not showcase how much I appreciate you nearly as much as I should.
Some reasons why you are great (just a few of the many!):
1. You have 184 windows in your house.

2. You reacted wonderfully to having a bat in our house but no heroic husband when my friend Jessie from Capital Camps trekked over to Baltimore to visit me.
3. You are thee most fit mother of 8 on the planet.
4. You are the most hardworking, dedicated bar/bat-mitzvah planner when it comes to your children. I'll always treasure my Voge magazine.

Thank you for prioritizing all of your wonderful kids before yourself (in all regards but exercising and responding to emails). We love you and think you are the very best!

A special shoutout to Grandma for her birthday, too!

T-3 days till we can reunite

item.title: My Spirit Animal
item.description:
Take this quiz to discover your spirit animal!

You may, but I did not need a quiz. I know that my spirit animal is the cheetah cub.

My baby and I:

You (above) are so much cuter and friendlier now than you will be very soon. Although it looks like I am getting along well with Zara below, truth be told, the girl jumped on and scratched me just moments earlier. Rawr.

item.title: Bungee Jumping
item.description:
I asked my parents if I should go bungee jumping. They said I should not.

Actually, they said I absolutely should not. But I wanted to- and nearly everyone else was- so I did! Woohoo!
Two days later I emailed the family home. Casually, I wrote:

"Check out your brave daughter/granddaughter/sister (at 216 meters, this is the highest bungee jump in the world from a bridge, and the second highest in the world overall--China's tower is slightly higher):"

(I included a video attachment.)

Their responses:

My sister Aviva:
"SO COOL!!!!!"

My father:
"U r crazy!!!"

My sister Arielle:
"Wow amazing! You jumped so quickly, so brave!!""

My mother:
"Unbelievable! I would NEVER EVER try that, and UPSIDE DOWN! Were you nauseous? Any fears? I guess you'll have to check out China's now--then again, DON'T!! THAT WAS ENOUGH!! Thank you for not telling me in advance. I guess you didn't have to have your parent or guardian sign for you. Just come home alive and well! Thanks for sharing, love and kisses, Mommy"

So what do we learn from that? I guess that 1) I am brave, 2) I am crazy fun, and 3) I have crazy good judgment. Thank you and goodnight.

item.title: Do I miss home yet?
item.description:
I fear I might develop carpool tunnel syndrome.

I bought all of these beautiful postcards at the giftshop of the Botanical Gardens in Kierstenbosch. They all remain in my laptop case. As I leave Cape Town for Baltimore in two days, I figure it's best to mail my already-written postcards from Baltimore. Yes, my grandparents will see me before they receive the postcards, but it's the thought that counts, eh? My hope is that they think the mail delivery system is weak, and so even though The Responsible Tali mailed the postcards home nearly 2 months ago, the postcards did not arrive before I arrived.

Well, this way I 1) save Rand on stamps and 2) avoid the precarious African mailing system that might lose my beautiful postcards FOREVER.

item.title: NSO
item.description:
New Student Orientation

I no longer am a freshman, but that does not mean NSO is not for me. I like to party, and so NSO certainly is for me. This week is the only time of the year when students get to be together on campus without having any responsibilities, unless you include buying textbooks and furniture. I already got most of mine, though, so bring on the Franzia. Just kidding.

So I've gotten to experience this majestic week once. As a freshman, though, I had some limitations. I was told I had to attend many New Student events, including a summer reading lecture, multiple safety lectures, awkward Hall Meet And Greets, and a Hebrew placement test (which I bombed on 2 hours of sleep--!◊ë◊ï◊©◊î).

I studied at HebrewU for an entire semester and yet I couldn't manage to place out of Hebrew!

Don't get me wrong, I attended about 1/4 of these events. But knowing I was supposed to attend each one of them did taint my experience, as skipping each event for a party forced me to be slightly anxious and fearful of getting caught as I entered each frat house rather than lecture hall. Luckily the Fireball helped to ease my nerves. Again, kidding.

I remember attending Theos' NSO pool party with the intention of leaving early in order to make it in time to my preceptorial called, "Espionage: how to catch a spy." Although the preceptorial was optional, I had signed up for it because the topic interested me so much. I had told my grandfather all about it, and he requested I ask the professor how I can catch James Bond. I knew Gramps would be disappointed if I skipped the class in order to stay at the pool party. Sorry, Gramps. I don't think I would've gotten the answer, anyway.

Me and friends at the pool party:


Penn provides freshmen and not upperclassmen with free meals throughout NSO. But having these meals without any time to eat them just made me feel foolish!

Lastly, I didn't know that many people at last year's NSO. Now I have lots of friends (or so I like to think...)!

All of these factors have influenced me to believe this year's NSO will be better than last year's. And last year's was pretty fun. C u there.

ALSO, I am beyond excited to move in with these gals:

Email me if you are interested in attending one of our (soon-to-be) famous Shabbat Dinners! You don't even need to be Jewish, all are welcome.

item.title: Keeping Shabbat
item.description:
I believe the Sabbath; I keep the Sabbath. - John Harvey Kellogg
Don't I??

I keep Shabbat. No, I do not attend shul every Friday night and Saturday (although my Saturday attendance record is decent if counting all the times I've arrived at noon, just in time for the kiddushim. My father made sure to walk by to my house from services to pull me and my four sisters out of bed whenever Yaffa is catering, a big-donor is sponsoring, or there is really good chullent.
No, I do not usually light the Friday night candles. I sometimes talk during shalom aleichem. I've gone thru quite a few Shabbatot when I have not paused for a single moment to think about G-d.

So, you might be thinking: 'FAKE!' Or, maybe: 'It doesn't sound like you keep Shab for G-d, so why do you burden yourself with it?'
My answers: 1) F all the h8ers. 2) I do it for myself. Carry on, eager readers!

Sometimes keeping Shabbat is really, really easy.

Sometimes I'm in Israel- then it's simple. And when I keep it with my family, I virtually am being spoon-fed my obligation.

And sometimes it's really damn hard.

Like when I'm stuck on Long Street in Africa, or when I've just completed a half-marathon and am stuck 13 miles away from my destination and it's pouring down rain.

I really want to love Shabbat. If refusing to allow myself to turn the light off before bed will cause me to begrudge Shabbat, shouldn't I just hit the damn switch? What's the big deal? Isn't it more important that I maintain a favorable opinion of the Sabbath?

I've learned that there's no compromising. If you want to do Shabbat, commit to it. Fully fledge.

If I go to a Shabbat dinner with the plan of attending a frat party or Club 31 after, even if my plan is to walk there so that I will not "break" Shabbat, my head is going to be in the wrong place the whole time I am trying to "do" Shabbat and I will not be able to enjoy it. I will detest every d'var torah that I otherwise would've considered beautiful, simply because I will be in a rush. I will hate any schmoozing that takes place amongst all the guests who are doing Shabbat correctly. Celebrating Shabbat all-or-nothing commitment.

"More than the Jewish People have kept the Sabbath, the Sabbath has kept the Jews." - Ahad Ha'am

item.title: Assembly Wednesdays in Cape Town
item.description:
‚ÄúI have Social Disease. I have to go out every night. If I stay home one night I start spreading rumours to my dogs.‚Äù ‚Äï Andy Warhol

Pictures of me and my friends at Assembly:

When you are the only one at the club, you tend to make it into a decent number of pictures.

Our dear friend Kale (his real name is Karol but he finds our nickname for him endearing) works at the front desk of our Cape Town hostel. However, he is not always on duty...

item.title: I performed comedy in the talent show
item.description:
There were two whales swimming in the ocean.

When I hear about a talent show, signing up for it is not a question. Not because I‚Äôm full of talents, but because my mother taught me always to participate. Unfortunately, she did not pass onto me the talent of having an incredible voice, or being able to juggle, or being able to burp the ABCs (she can do that, so it‚Äôs really unfair that I can‚Äôt).

What I can do: hula hoop walk on stilts do a split do a decent cartwheel do a handstand (sometimes - other times I fall over) blow spit bubbles read poetry (in the sense that I am literate)

When iXperience announced it was hosting a talent show, I immediately signed myself up for an act with my bffs, Rebecca & Menachem. We knew our next step was to brainstorm our talent.

We considered our skills. Since we‚Äôre in Africa, we could not get hula hoops or stilts.

We considered performing a Peisach Seder onstage. We decided that could be a chillul Hashem.

We chose to do comedy. Please enjoy this video. Please ROFL (this is one of the ONLY times it is okay for this ‚ÄòROFL‚Äô phrase to be used - it is okay now because my hope is that you react to this video by rolling on the floor laughing. I am a literal person, though, and do not appreciate when people respond ‚ÄòROFL‚Äô to jokes that probably fail even to make them smile.).

The infamous whale joke:

The hip-pain joke:

Another instance where ‚ÄòROFL‚Äô is appropriate:

MUST SEE Adam goldstien Trying to jump a 5th pole outside walmart

Video Uploaded

Posted by Avi Dresin on Wednesday, August 18, 2010
